crox:store iso4217:EUR crox:item xbrli:pure xbrli:shares iso4217:USD xbrli:shares iso4217:USD 2735000 8722000 2150000 0 4900000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Activity within our accumulated other comprehensive income (&#x201C;AOCI&#x201D;) balance consists solely of gains and losses resulting from the translation of foreign subsidiary financial statements to our reporting currency. Foreign currency translation resulting in changes to other comprehensive income and related reclassification adjustments are presented net of tax effects on the consolidated statements of other comprehensive income. Foreign currency reclassification adjustments are included within the line item entitled &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction gains (losses), net&#x2019; on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 12276000 12276000 198000000 990 3680000 11828000 3441000 9874000 3656000 6857000 13609000 18783000 10513000 32392000 <div> <div style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.25pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>(7,065) </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.10%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.25pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.10%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.25pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:09.82%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.25pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>9,874&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 1900000 2500000 P2Y6M 8200000 400000 13793100 34000 61000 58840 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Beneficial conversion feature</font><font style="display: inline;"> &#x2014; The issuance of our Series A Preferred Stock generated a beneficial conversion feature, which arises when a debt or equity security is issued with an embedded conversion option that is beneficial to the investor or in the money at inception because the conversion option has an effective strike price that is less than the market price of the underlying stock at the commitment date. We recognized the beneficial conversion feature by allocating the intrinsic value of the conversion option, which is the number of shares of common stock available upon conversion multiplied by the difference between the effective conversion price per share and the fair value of common stock per share on the commitment date, to additional paid-in capital, resulting in a discount on the Series A Preferred Stock. We are accreting the discount over </font><font style="display: inline;">eight</font><font style="display: inline;"> years from the date of issuance through the redemption date. Accretion expense will be recognized as dividend equivalents over the eight year period utilizing the effective interest method.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 0 700000 200000 100000 100000 247600000 37870000 37870000 23326000 23326000 26800000 10800000 2166000 5111000 1930000 13888000 12087000 23099000 8500000 9700000 9600000 29.00 14.50 1364000 9343000 6551000 16102000 14230000 5176000 5288000 767000 2015-12-01 2015-01-01 15800000 3985000 0.06 0.046 0.034 1.158 0.019 -0.184 16800000 P2Y 3706000 2593000 1000 1112000 2280000 1240000 1000 1039000 1342000 -843000 2185000 783000 -29000 715000 -22000 853000 -46000 0.0125 0.0115 2400000 9700000 17700000 1100000 19500000 54200000 388745 43000 78000 144000 12565000 12110000 1804000 445000 600000 100000 200000 4100000 4100000 900000 -4900000 0 0 5250000 11540000 140455000 177507000 3400000 11500000 2000000 5700000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">17\. </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We and certain current and former officers and directors were named as defendants in complaints filed by investors in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado. The first complaint was filed in November 2007 and several other complaints were filed shortly thereafter. These actions were consolidated and, in September 2008, the district court appointed a lead plaintiff and counsel. An amended consolidated complaint was filed in December 2008. The amended complaint purported to state claims under Sections&nbsp;10(b), 20(a), and 20A of the Exchange Act on behalf of a class of all persons who purchased our common stock between April&nbsp;2, 2007 and April&nbsp;14, 2008 (the "Class Period"). The amended complaint also added our independent auditor as a defendant. The amended complaint alleged that, during the Class Period, the defendants made false and misleading public statements about us and our business and prospects and, as a result, the market price of our common stock was artificially inflated. The amended complaint also claimed that certain current and former officers and directors traded in our common stock on the basis of material non-public information. The amended complaint sought compensatory damages on behalf of the alleged class in an unspecified amount, including interest, and also sought attorneys' fees and costs of litigation. On February&nbsp;28, 2011, the District Court granted motions to dismiss filed by the defendants and dismissed all claims. A final judgment was thereafter entered. Plaintiffs subsequently appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. We and those current and former officers and directors named as defendants entered into a Stipulation of Settlement with the plaintiffs to resolve all claims asserted against us by the plaintiffs on behalf of the putative class. Our independent auditor was not a party to the Stipulation of Settlement. The Stipulation of Settlement received preliminary approval from the District Court on August&nbsp;28, 2013. On September 18, 2014, the District Court entered an order of final approval of the settlement and, on September 19, 2014, the District Court entered final judgment dismissing the action against us and those current and former officers and directors named as defendants in its entirety</font><font style="display: inline;"> with prejudice. </font><font style="display: inline;">The full settlement amount </font><font style="display: inline;">has been paid by our insurers. </font><font style="display: inline;">Since no notice of appeal was filed during the appeal period, this action is now terminated as to Crocs a</font><font style="display: inline;">nd its affiliated individuals. </font><font style="display: inline;">Crocs considers this matter closed.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We are currently subject to an audit by U.S. Customs &amp; Border Protection (&#x201C;CBP&#x201D;) in respect of the period from 2006 to 2010.&nbsp;&nbsp;In October 2013, CBP issued the final audit report.&nbsp;In that report CBP projects that unpaid duties totaling approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">12.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million are due for the period under review and recommends</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> collection of the duties due. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We responded that these projections are erroneous and provided arguments that demonstrate the amount due in connection with this matte</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">r is considerably less than the pr</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ojecti</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">on.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Additionally, on December 12, 2014, we made an offer to settle CBP&#x2019;s potential cla</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ims and tendered $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">3.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">At this time, it is not possible to determine how long it will take CBP to evaluate our offer or to predict whether our offer will be accepted.&nbsp;&nbsp;Likewise, if a settlement cannot be reached, it is not possible to predict with any certainty whether CBP will seek to assert a claim for penalties in addition to any unpaid duties, but such an assertion is a possibility.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Mexico&#x2019;s Federal Tax Authority (&#x201C;SAT&#x201D;) has audited the company&#x2019;s records regarding imports and exports during the period from January 2006 to July 2011.&nbsp;There were two phases to the audit, the first for capital equipment and finished goods and the second for raw materials.&nbsp; The first phase was completed and no major discre</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">pancies were noted by the SAT.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On January 9, 2013, Crocs received a notice for the second phase in which the SAT issued a tax assessment (taxes and penalties) of roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">280.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million pesos (approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">22.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million) based on the value of all of Crocs&#x2019; imported raw mate</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rials during the audit period.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We believe that the proposed penalty amount is unfounded and without merit. With the help of local counsel we filed an appeal by t</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">he deadline of March 15, 2013.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We have argued that the amount due in connection with the matter, if any, is substantially less </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">than that proposed by the SAT.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In connection with the appeal, the SAT required us to post an appeal surety bond in the amount of roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">321.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million pesos (approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">26.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million), which amount reflects estimated additional penalties and interest if we are</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> not successful on our appeal.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">This amount will be adjusted on an annual basis. On November 27, 2014, the Superior Chamber of the Federal Tax Court ruled in favor of Crocs and annulled the tax assessment </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">and the corresponding penalty. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs anticipates that th</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">e SAT will appeal this ruling. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter or reasonably estimate any potential loss.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs is currently subject to an audit by the Brazilian Federal Tax Authorities related to imports of footwear</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> from China between 2010-2014. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On January 13, 2015 Crocs was not</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ified about the issuance of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">assessments totaling roughly $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">5.25</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million for the period </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">January 2010 through May 2011. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs has disputed </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">these</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> assessment</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and as</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">serted defenses to the claims. On February </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">25, 201</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">5,</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Crocs received additional assessments totaling roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$11.54</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million related to the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">remainder of the audit period. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs is in the process of reviewing these assessments, however, it expects to contest and file defenses to these claims as well. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, we have accrued a total </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">5.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> relating to these litigati</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">on matters and other disputes. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We estimate that the ultimate resolution of these litigation matters and other disputes could result in a loss that is reasonably possible between $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.0 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million and $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">9.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million in the aggregate, in excess of the amount accrued.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Although we are subject to other litigation from time to time in the ordinary course of business, including employment, intellectual property and product liability claims, we are not party to any other pending legal proceedings that we believe would reasonably have a material adverse impact on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Noncontrolling Interests</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 201</font><font </font></p> </div> </div> 1755000 1207000 18379000 17832000 3 3 3 P20D 5 5 4 4 60 23 2 35 77 36 14 27 4 35 23 2 36 14 27 20 100 75 130698000 10384000 -18962000 700000 600000 3600000 3100000 3500000 280000000 22000000 0.08 0.05 0.05 0.460 P8Y 1.01 1.00 P8Y 35500000 1100000 12400000 3500000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;text-decoration:underline;">Going Concern</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:12pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On August 27, 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-15, which provides guidance on determining when and how reporting entities must disclose going concern uncertainties in their financial statements. The new standard requires management to perform interim and annual assessments of an entity&#x2019;s ability to continue as a going concern within one year of the date of issuance of the entity&#x2019;s financial statements (or within one year after the date on which the financial statements are available to be issued, when applicable). Further, an entity must provide certain disclosures if there is &#x201C;substantial doubt about the entity&#x2019;s ability to continue as a going concern.&#x201D;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The FASB believes that requiring management to perform the assessment will enhance the timeliness, clarity and consistency of related disclosures and improve convergence with IFRSs (which emphasize management&#x2019;s responsibility for performing the going concern assessment). However, the time horizon for the assessment (look-forward period) and the disclosure thresholds under U.S. GAAP and IFRSs will continue to differ. This ASU is effective for annual periods ending after December 16, 2016, and interim periods thereafter; early adoption is permitted. The Company does not believe that this pronouncement will have a material impact </font><font style="display: inline;">on our financial statement disclosures.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;text-decoration:underline;">Share-Based Payment</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:12pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On June 19, 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-12 in response to the EITF consensus on Issue 13-D. The ASU clarifies that entities should treat performance targets that can be met after the requisite service period of a share-based payment award as performance conditions that affect vesting. Therefore, an entity would not record compensation expense related to an award for which transfer to the employee is contingent on the entity&#x2019;s satisfaction of a performance target until it becomes probable that the performance target will be met. The ASU does not contain any new disclosure requirements. This ASU is effective for all entities for reporting periods (including interim periods) beginning after December 15, 2015. The Company does not believe that this pronouncement will have a material impact to the Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial statements.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;text-decoration:underline;">Revenue Recognition</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:12pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In May 2014, the FASB issued their final standard on revenue from contracts with customers. The standard, issued as ASU No. 2014-09: </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606)</font><font style="display: inline;"> by the FASB, outlines a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, including industry-specific guidance. The core principle of the revenue model is that &#x201C;an entity recognizes revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.&#x201D; In applying the revenue model to contracts within its scope, an entity:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Symbol;">&#xF0B7;</font><font style="display: inline;"> Identifies the contract(s) with a customer (Step 1)</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Symbol;">&#xF0B7;</font><font style="display: inline;"> Identifies the performance obligations in the contract (Step 2)</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Symbol;">&#xF0B7;</font><font style="display: inline;"> Determines the transaction price (Step 3)</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Symbol;">&#xF0B7;</font><font style="display: inline;"> Allocates the transaction price to the performance obligations in the contract (Step 4)</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Symbol;">&#xF0B7;</font><font style="display: inline;"> Recognizes revenue when (or as) the entity satisfies a performance obligation (Step 5)</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The ASU applies to all contracts with customers except those that are within the scope of other topics in the FASB Accounting Standards Codification. Certain of the ASU&#x2019;s provisions also apply to transfers of nonfinancial assets, including in-substance nonfinancial assets that are not an output of an entity&#x2019;s ordinary activities (e.g., sales of property, plant, and equipment, real estate or intangible assets). Existing accounting guidance applicable to these transfers has been amended or superseded. Compared with current U.S. GAAP, the ASU also requires significantly expanded disclosures about revenue recognition.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The ASU is effective for annual reporting periods (including interim reporting periods within those periods) beginning after December 15, 2016. Early application is not permitted. The Company is currently evaluating the impact that this pronouncement will have on the Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial statements.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:22.50pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:center;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;color:#000000;font-size:8pt;">Number of stores</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:01.72%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="width:10.72%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:22.50pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:center;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;color:#000000;font-size:8pt;">Impairment charge</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:01.72%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:22.50pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:center;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:09.00%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:22.50pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:center;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;color:#000000;font-size:8pt;">Number of stores</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:01.60%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">Performance&nbsp;Goal</font></p> </td> <td valign="top" style="border-right:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt solid #000000 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 9pt;margin:0pt;"> <sup style="margin:0pt;font-size:9pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-family:Times New Roman;;"> (3)</sup> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p 9pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">Includes $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">6.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> million for the year ended December 31, 2013 of asset impairment charges related to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">35</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> underperforming retail locations.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 9pt;margin:0pt;"> <sup style="margin:0pt;font-size:9pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-family:Times New Roman;;"> (4)</sup> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 9pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">Includes </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">2.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">million for the year ended December 31, 2014 of asset impairment charges related to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">27</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> underperforming retail locations.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <sup style="margin:0pt;font-size:9pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-family:Times New Roman;;"> (5)</sup> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">Includes a corporate component consisting primarily of corporate support and administrative functions, costs associated with share-based compensation, research and development, brand marketing, legal, restructuring, depreciation and amortization of corporate and other assets not allocated to operating segments and costs of the same nature related to certain corporate holding companies. See Note 6 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&#x2013; &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">Restructuring for additional details. </font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 1100000 1000000 P1Y P1Y P1Y P1Y P1Y P1Y P1Y 0.50 0.50 0.50 0.50 0.70 0.70 0.70 0.90 P2Y P2Y P1Y P1Y 2.00 0.50 2.00 0.50 2.00 2.00 0.50 0.50 400000 400000 900000 400000 900000 300000 1000 P5Y P3Y 321000000 26000000 2200000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Taxes Assessed by Governmental Authorities</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Taxes assessed by governmental authorities that are directly imposed on a revenue transaction, including value added tax, are recorded on a net basis and are therefore excluded from sales.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">14\. SERIES A PREFERRED STOCK</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">On January&nbsp;27, 2014, we issued to </font><font style="display: inline;">Blackstone, together with </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">the Blackstone Purchasers, </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">200,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> shares</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> of our Series A Preferred Stock for an aggregate purchase price of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">$198.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">&nbsp;million, or </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">$990</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> per share, pursuant to an Investment Agreement between us and Blackstone, dated December&nbsp;28, 2013 (as amended, the &#x201C;Investment Agreement&#x201D;). In connection with the issuance of the Series A Preferred Stock (the &#x201C;Closing&#x201D;), we received proceeds of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">$182.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> million after deducting the issuance discount of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">$2.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> million and direct and incremental expenses of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">$15.8</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> million including financial advisory fees, closing costs, legal expenses and other offering-related expenses.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Participation Rights and Dividends</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">The Series A Preferred Stock ranks senior to our common stock with respect to dividend rights and rights on liquidation, winding-up and dissolution. The Series A Preferred Stock has a stated value of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">$1,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> per share, and holders of Series A Preferred Stock are entitled to cumulative dividends payable quarterly in cash at a rate of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">6%</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> per annum. If we fail to make timely dividend payments, the dividend rate will increase to </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">8%</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> per annum until such time as all accrued but unpaid dividends have been paid in full. Holders of Series A Preferred Stock are entitled to receive dividends declared or paid on our common stock and are entitled to vote together with the holders of our common stock as a single class, in </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">each case, on an as-converted basis. As of December 31, 2014, we have accrued dividends of $</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">3.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> million on the consolidated balance sheets, which were paid in cash to </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">holders of the Series A Preferred Stock</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> on January 2, 2015. Holders of Series A Preferred Stock have certain limited special approval rights, including with respect to the issuance of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">pari passu</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> or senior equity securities of the Company.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Conversion Features</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">The Series A Preferred Stock is convertible at the option of the holders at any time after the Closing into shares of common stock at an implied conversion price of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">$14.50</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> per share, subject to adjustment. At our election, all or a portion of the Series A Preferred Stock will be convertible into the relevant number of shares of common stock on or after the third anniversary of the Closing, if the closing price of the common stock equals or exceeds </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">$29.00</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> for </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">20</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> consecutive trading days. The Series A Preferred Stock is convertible into </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">13,793,100</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> shares of our common stock based on the conversio</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n rate in place as of December 31, 2014. The conversion rate is subject to the following customary anti-dilution and other adjustments:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:36pt;"><p style="width:36pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 1)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">The occurrence of common stock dividends or distributions, stock splits or combinations, and equity reclassifications.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:36pt;"><p style="width:36pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 2)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">The distribution of rights, options, or warrants to all holders of common stock entitling them to purchase shares of common stock at a price per share that is less than the closing price of the Company&#x2019;s common stock.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:36pt;"><p style="width:36pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 3)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">Pursuant to a tender offer or exchange offer to purchase outstanding shares of common stock for consideration valued at an amount greater than the closing price of the Company&#x2019;s common stock.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:36pt;"><p style="width:36pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 4)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">If the Company distributes evidences of its indebtedness, assets, other property or securities or rights, options or warrants to acquire its Capital Stock.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:36pt;"><p style="width:36pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 5)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">If the Company has any stockholder rights plan in effect with respect to the common stock on the date of conversion, upon conversion of the Series A Preferred Stock, the holder will also receive (in addition to the common stock pursuant to the conversion) the rights under such rights plan, unless those rights (a) become exercisable before the conversion of the Series A Preferred Stock, or (b) are separated from the common stock (each a &#x201C;Trigger Event&#x201D;).&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon the occurrence of a Trigger Event, the Series A Preferred Stock conversion rate will be adjusted in accordance with 1) or 2) described above.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:36pt;"><p style="width:36pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 6)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">If the Company issues shares of common stock&nbsp;&nbsp;(or&nbsp;&nbsp;other instruments convertible into common stock) for valuable consideration, the conversion price is adjusted if (a) the offering price is less than the conversion price and (b) if the offering is at a price less than the fair market value of the Company&#x2019;s common stock on the date of issuance.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">Redemption Features</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">At any time after the eighth anniversary of the Closing, we will have the right to redeem and the holders of the Series A Preferred Stock will have the right to require us to repurchase, all or any portion of the Series A Preferred Stock at </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">100%</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> of the stated value thereof plus all accrued but unpaid dividends. Upon certain change of control events involving us, the holders can require us to repurchase the Series A Preferred Stock at </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">101%</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> of the stated value thereof plus all accrued but unpaid dividends. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">In accordance with FASB ASC Topic 480-10-S99-3A, </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">SEC Staff Announcement: Classification and Measurement of Redeemable Securities</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">, redemption features which are not solely within the control of the issuer are required to be presented outside of permanent equity on the consolidated balance sheets. Under the Investment Agreement and as noted above, the holder has the option to redeem the Series A Preferred Stock any time after January 27, 2022 or upon a change in control. As such, the Series A Preferred Stock is presented in temporary or mezzanine equity on the consolidated balance sheets and will be accreted up to the stated redemption value of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$203.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> million using an appropriate accretion method over a redemption period of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">eight</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> year</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">s, as this represents the earliest probable date at which the Series A Preferred Stock will become redeemable.</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 0.035 0.068 2.944 10000 342000 450400000 1300000 109500000 19500000 2400000 3300000 P1Y1M24D P1Y9M11D P2Y6M P4M10D P1Y5M27D 14.99 13.75 P30D P30D P30D false \--12-31 FY 2014 2014-12-31 10-K 0001334036 77834494 Yes Large Accelerated Filer 1300000000 Crocs, Inc. ACCRUED EXPENSES AND OTHER CURRENT LIABILITIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table summarizes </tr> </table></div><hr style="border-bottom-style:solid;width:25%;height:.75pt; ;color:#000000" align="left"></hr> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%">(1)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%;font-size: 10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt;padding:0pt 13.5pt 0pt 0pt;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-size:3pt;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">The amounts in Other consist of various accrued expenses and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">no</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> individual item accounted for more than </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">5%</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> of the total balance as of December 31, 2014 or 2013.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Asset Retirement Obligations</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We record a liability equal to the fair value of the estimated future cost to retire an asset, if the liability&#x2019;s fair value can be reasonably estimated. Our asset retirement obligation (&#x201C;ARO&#x201D;) liabilities are primarily associated with the disposal of property and equipment which we are contractually obligated to remove at the end of certain retail and office leases in order to restore the facilities back original condition as specified in the related lease agreements. We estimate the fair value of these liabilities based on current store closing costs and discount the costs back as if they were to be performed at the inception of the lease. At the inception of such leases, we record the ARO as a liability and also record a related asset in an amount equal to the estimated fair value of the obligation. The capitalized asset is then depreciated on a straight-line basis over the useful life of the asset. Upon retirement of the ARO liability, any difference between the actual retirement costs incurred and the previously recorded estimated ARO liability is recognized as a gain or loss in the consolidated statements of operations.</font><font style="display: inline;"> Our ARO liability as of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">was $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.2 </font><font style="display: inline;">million</font><font style="display: inline;"> and</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">2.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> respectively.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 57450000 42923000 104405000 101217000 15992000 9078000 36616000 8843000 97111000 80216000 14128000 16212000 12198000 9675000 98151000 99799000 14652000 -18352000 321532000 345732000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Advertising</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and production costs </font><font style="display: inline;">are </font><font style="display: inline;">expensed when the advertising is first run. Total advertising, marketing and promotional costs reflected in &#x2018;Selling, general, and administrative expenses&#x2019; on the consolidated statement of operations </font><font style="display: inline;">were $</font><font style="display: inline;">44.7 </font><font style="display: inline;">million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">7.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">39.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 39800000 47600000 44700000 11300000 12500000 12700000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 14pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">11</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. style="width:02.10%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.25pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:09.82%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.25pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>9,874&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 3700000 11600000 11500000 11764000 11764000 14483000 14483000 14896000 14896000 13600000 17200000 14200000 1400000 1000000 2000000 1410000 10949000 6600000 8827000 2000000 2200000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We record a liability equal to the fair value of the estimated future cost to retire an asset, if the liability&#x2019;s fair value can be reasonably estimated. Our asset retirement obligation (&#x201C;ARO&#x201D;) liabilities are primarily associated with the disposal of property and equipment which we are contractually obligated to remove at the end of certain retail and office leases in order to restore the facilities back original condition as specified in the related lease agreements. We estimate the fair value of these liabilities based on current store closing costs and discount the costs back as if they were to be performed at the inception of the lease. At the inception of such leases, we record the ARO as a liability and also record a related asset in an amount equal to the estimated fair value of the obligation. The capitalized asset is then depreciated on a straight-line basis over the useful life of the asset. Upon retirement of the ARO liability, any difference between the actual retirement costs incurred and the previously recorded estimated ARO liability is recognized as a gain or loss in the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 875159000 806931000 640077000 14093000 63743000 506054000 51155000 139855000 177343000 137701000 595408000 18132000 27337000 494272000 34032000 127077000 166878000 166285000 4251000 2368000 2165000 771000 200000 200000 257587000 294348000 317144000 267512000 36761000 22796000 -49632000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Cash and Cash Equivalents</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Cash and cash equivalents represent cash and short-term, highly liquid investments with maturities of three months or less at the date of purchase. We consider receivables from credit card companies to be cash equivalents, if expected to be received within five days.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">15</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. COMMITMENTS AND CONTINGENCIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Rental Commitments and Contingencies</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We rent space for our retail stores, offices, warehouses, vehicles, and equipment under operating leases expiring at various dates through 2033.</font><font style="display: inline;"> Certain leases contain rent escalation clauses (step rents) that require additional rental amounts in the later years of the term. Rent expense for leases with step rents or rent holidays is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term beginning on the lease inception date. Deferred rent is included in the consolidated balance sheets in &#x2018;Accrued expenses and other current liabilities.&#x2019;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 4pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Future minimum annual rental commitments under non-cancelable operating leases for each of the five succeeding years as of </font><font They also do not include contingent rentals which may be paid under certain retail leases on a basis of percentage of sales in excess of stipulated amounts.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#252525;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#252525;">The following table summarizes the composition of rent expense under ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Purchase Commitments</font> </p> <p 12pt;color:#252525;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of December 31, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had </font><font style="display: inline;">firm </font><font style="display: inline;">purchase commitments with certain third-party manufacturers </font><font style="display: inline;">of $</font><font style="display: inline;">202.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;"> and </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">172.3</font><font Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In </font><font style="display: inline;">December</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;2011, we renewed and amended our supply agreement with Finproject S.</font><font style="display: inline;">p</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font><font style="display: inline;">A. (formerly known as Finproject s.r.l.), </font><font style="display: inline;">which provides us the exclusive right to purchase certain raw materials used to manufacture our products. The agreement also provides that we meet minimum purchase requirements to maintain exclusivity throughout the term</font><font style="display: inline;"> of the agreement, which expires</font><font style="display: inline;"> December&nbsp;31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">6</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">Historically, the minimum purchase requirements have not been onerous and we do not expect them to become onerous in the future. Depending on the material purchased, pricing was either based on contracted price or was subject to quarterly reviews and fluctuates based on order volume, currency fluctuations and raw material prices. Pursuant to the agreement, we guarantee the payment for certain third-party manufacturer purchases of these raw materials up to a maximum potential amount of </font><font style="display: inline;">&#x20AC;3.5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million (approximately </font><font style="display: inline;">$4.3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million as of December 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">), through a letter of credit that was issued to Finproject S.</font><font style="display: inline;">p</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font><font style="display: inline;">A</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Government Tax Audits</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We are regularly subject to, and are currently undergoing, audits by tax authorities in the United States and several foreign jurisdictions for prior tax years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In April&nbsp;2013, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Brazil&#x2019;s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> State of Sao Paulo, Brazil government (&#x201C;Brazil&#x201D;) assessed sales taxes, interest and penalties for the period April&nbsp;2009 to May&nbsp;2011.&nbsp;We had previously tendered these taxes using Brazil obligations purchased at a discount from third parties. On&nbsp;May&nbsp;22, 2013, we&nbsp;applied for amnesty in order to receive a significant reduction in penalties and interest, agreed to amend our 2009&nbsp;through&nbsp;2012&nbsp;tax returns to remove the Brazil obligations, and agreed to settle the assessment in cash to Brazil. In June&nbsp;2013, cash payment was made to Brazil, in full satisfaction of the Brazil assessment</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and amended tax returns</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. Brazil is&nbsp;making&nbsp;court-ordered&nbsp;payments to&nbsp;holders of&nbsp;the Brazil obligations along with accrued interest. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We anticipate</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> that the Brazil obligations (plus accrued interest) will be paid by Brazil in accordance with the court-orders</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, however, during the year ended December 31, 2014, we reserved</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">entire carrying balance of the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Brazil </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">obligation.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> The net impact of the above is a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">3.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million charge to operating income recorded during the year ended December 31, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">2014\. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">A</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s of December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">,</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">t</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">he</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> carrying balance of the Brazil obligations </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">was</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$3.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million, which </font><font style="display:
