inline;font-size:10pt;">. The net impact of the above is a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$6.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million charge to operating income recorded during the year ended December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In April 2014, we received a final notice of assessment on transfer pricing items from the Canadian tax authorities, which closed the ongoing audit of our Canada operations through 2011. The assessment, along with the estimated impact on certain Canadian provinces, was less than the amount of the uncertain tax benefits recorded, and therefore, resulted in a net tax benefit of approximately </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">2.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in the quarter ended June 30, 2014. We have paid the assessment, which included tax and interest for the tax periods through December 31, 2011.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">See </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Note 17 &#x2013; Legal</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Proceedings for further details regarding potential loss contingencies related to government tax audits and other current legal proceedings.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 0.001 0.001 250000000 250000000 91662656 92325201 88450203 78516566 197534 3500000 2000000 6000000 92000 92000 136210000 5384000 -37930000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Concentrations of Risk</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;We are exposed to concentrations of risks in the following categories:</font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Cash and cash equivalents</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;Our cash and cash equivalents are maintained in several different financial institutions in amounts that typically exceed U.S. federally insured limits or in financial institutions in international jurisdictions where insurance is not provided and restrictions may exist. </font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As we are a global business, we have cash and cash equivalent balances which are located in various countries and are denominated in various currencies. Most of the cash balances held outside of the U.S. could be repatriated to the U.S., but under current law, would be subject to U.S. federal and state income taxes less applicable foreign tax credits. In some countries, repatriation of certain foreign balances is restricted by local laws and could have adverse tax consequences if we were to move the cash to another country. Certain countries, including China, have monetary laws which may limit our ability to utilize cash resources in those countries for operations in other countries. These limitations may affect our ability to fully utilize our cash and cash equivalent resources for needs in the U.S. or other countries and could </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">adversely affect our liquidity. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, we held </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$247.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million of our total </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">267.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million in cash in international locations. This cash is primarily used for the ongoing operations of the business in the locations in which the cash is held. Of the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$247.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million held in international locations, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$10.8</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million could potentially be restricted, as described above. </font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On January 27, 2014, we issued to Blackstone Capital Partners</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> VI L.P. (&#x201C;Blackstone&#x201D;), and certain of its permitted transferees (together with Blackstone, the &#x201C;Blackstone Purchasers&#x201D;), </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">200,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> shares of our Series A Preferred Stock. In return, we received approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$182.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million in cash proceeds (net of related expenses) all of which is held in the U.S. See Note&nbsp;1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">4&#x2014;Series A </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Preferred Stock for further detail regarding the investment agreement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Accounts receivable</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;We have not experienced significant losses in such accounts in prior years, however, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">as of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">December 31, 2014, we recorded a reserve for doubtful accounts of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$11.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million in our Asia Pacific segment primarily as a result of delayed payments from our partner stores in China and Southeast Asia</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and a reserve for rebates on a consolidated basis of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$11.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million primarily related to our Asia Pacific region.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As of December 31, 2013, our reserve for doubtful accounts was </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$3.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million and the rebates reserve was </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$1.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Generally, we consider any concentration of credit risk related to accounts receivable to be mitigated by our credit policy, the insignificance of outstanding balances owed by each individual customer at any point in time and the geographic dispersion of our customers.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> See Note 11&#x2014;Allowances for further detail.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Manufacturing sources</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We rely on a limited source of internal and external manufacturers. Establishing a replacement source could require significant additional time and expense. </font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Suppliers of certain raw materials</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;We source the elastomer resins that constitute the primary raw materials used in compounding Croslite, which we use to produce our footwear products, from multiple suppliers. If the suppliers we rely on for elastomer resins were to cease production of these materials, we may not be able to obtain suitable substitute materials in time to avoid interruption of our production cycle, if at all. We may also have to pay materially higher prices in the future for the elastomer resins or any substitute materials we use, which would increase our production costs and could have a materially adverse impact on our margins and results of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Basis of Consolidation</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;The consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (&#x201C;U.S. GAAP&#x201D;). The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of our wholly-owned subsidiaries as well as variable interest entities (&#x201C;VIE&#x201D;) for which we are the primary beneficiary after the elimination of intercompany accounts and transactions. The primary beneficiary of a VIE is the entity that has (i) the power to direct the activities of the VIE that most significantly impact the VIE&#x2019;s economic performance and (ii) the obligation to absorb losses of the VIE that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the VIE that could potentially be significant to the VIE. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In April 2011, we and an unrelated third party formed Crocs Gulf, LLC (&#x201C;Crocs Gulf&#x201D;) for the purpose of selling our products in the United Arab Emirates. We have determined that Crocs Gulf is a VIE for which we are the primary beneficiary due to our variable interest in Crocs Gulf&#x2019;s equity and because we currently control all of the VIE&#x2019;s business activities and will absorb all of its expected residual returns and expected losses. All voting and dividend rights have been assigned to us. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">, the consolidated financial statements </font><font style="display: inline;">included $</font><font style="display: inline;">3.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in total assets of Crocs Gulf, respectively, which primarily consisted of cash and cash equivalents, inventory, property and equipment. The total assets as </font><font style="display: inline;">of December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 2013 were partially </font><font style="display: inline;">offset by $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million </font><font style="display: inline;">and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in</font><font style="display: inline;"> total liabilities, </font><font style="display: inline;">respectively, </font><font style="display: inline;">which</font><font style="display: inline;"> primarily consisted of accounts payable and accrued expenses, excluding liabilities related to the support provided by us.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 16231000 3318000 515324000 569482000 603893000 4300000 6000000 4900000 4600000 2900000 1700000 -6364000 3311000 -12049000 22953000 22337000 7620000 17186000 26003000 -4452000 597000 355000 -23000 6940000 3075000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">9</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">REVOLVING CREDIT FACILITY &amp; </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">BANK BORROWINGS</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Revolving Credit Facility</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On September 25, 2009, we entered into a Revolving Credit and Security Agreement, as amended, with the lenders named therein and PNC Bank, National Association ("PNC"), as a lender and administrative agent for the lenders. On December 16, 2011, we entered into an Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (as amended, the &#x201C;Credit Agreement&#x201D;), and on December 27, 2013, we entered into the Third Amendment to Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the "Third Amendment"). The Third Amendment, among other things, (i) allowed for the payment of dividends on the Series A Convertible Preferred Stock ("Series A Preferred Stock"), (ii) permitted the Company to have greater flexibility to repurchase its Common Stock, (iii) decreased the maximum leverage ratio from </font><font style="display: inline;">3.50</font><font style="display: inline;"> to 1.00 to </font><font style="display: inline;">3.25</font><font style="display: inline;"> to 1.00, and (iv) amended certain definitions of the financial covenants to become more favorable to the Company. See Note 14&#x2014;Series A Preferred Stock for further details regarding the payment of dividends on the Series A Preferred Stock. On March 27, 2014, we entered into the Fourth Amendment to Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the &#x201C;Fourth Amendment&#x201D;). The Fourth Amendment primarily (i) altered the minimum fixed charge coverage ratio from </font><font style="display: inline;">1.25</font><font style="display: inline;"> to 1.00 to a scaled quarterly ratio of </font><font style="display: inline;">1.15</font><font style="display: inline;"> to 1.00 in the first and second quarters of 2014, </font><font style="display: inline;">1.20</font><font style="display: inline;"> to 1.00 in the third quarter of 2014, and (ii) amended certain definitions of the financial covenants to become more favorable to us.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On September 26, 2014, we entered into the Fifth Amendment to Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the &#x201C;Fifth Amendment&#x201D;), pursuant to which certain terms of the Credit Agreement were amended. The Fifth Amendment primarily (i) extended the minimum fixed charge coverage ratio of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">1.15</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 through the second quarter of 2015 and will return to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">1.25</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 for each quarter thereafter, and (ii) amended certain definitions of the financial covenants to become more favorable to us.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The Credit Agreement enables us to borrow up </font><font style="display: inline;">to </font><font style="display: inline;">$100.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, with the ability to increase commitments to up to </font><font style="display: inline;">$125.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;"> subject to certain conditions, and is currently set </font><font style="display: inline;">to mature on December 16, 2017. The Credit Agreement is available for working capital, capital expenditures, permitted acquisitions, reimbursement of drawings under letters of credit, and permitted dividends, distributions, purchases, redemptions and retirements of equity </font><font style="display: inline;">interests. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement are secured by all of our assets including all receivables, equipment, general intangibles, inventory, investment property, subsidiary stock and intellectual property. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement bear interest at a variable rate</font><font style="display: inline;">. For domestic rate loans, the interest rate is equal to the highest of (i) the daily federal funds open rate as quoted by ICAP North America, Inc. plus </font><font style="display: inline;">0.5%</font><font style="display: inline;">, (ii) PNC's prime rate and (iii) a daily LIBOR rate plus </font><font style="display: inline;">1.0%</font><font style="display: inline;">, in each case there is an additional margin ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;">0.25%</font><font style="display: inline;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;">1.00%</font><font style="display: inline;"> based on certain conditions. For LIBOR rate loans, the interest rate is equal to a LIBOR rate plus a margin ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;">1.25%</font><font style="display: inline;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;">2.00%</font><font style="display: inline;"> based on certain conditions. The Credit Agreement requires monthly interest payments with respect to domestic rate loans and at the end of each interest period with respect to LIBOR rate loans. The Credit Agreement further provides for a limit on the issuance of letters of credit to a maximum </font><font style="display: inline;">of </font><font style="display: inline;">$20.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">. The Credit Agreement contains provisions requiring us to maintain compliance with certain restrictive and financial covenants. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, we had </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement. As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, we had issued and outstanding letters of credit of </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$7.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, which were reserved against the borrowing base under the terms of the Credit Agreement. During the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, we capitalized </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, in fees and third party costs which were incurred in connection with the Credit Agreement, as deferred financing</font><font style="display: inline;"> costs. </font><font style="display: inline;">As of December 31, 2014, we were in compliance with all restrictive financial and other covenants under the Credit Agreement. </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Long-term Bank Borrowings</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On December 10, 2012, we entered into a Master Installment Payment Agreement (&#x201C;Master IPA&#x201D;) with PNC in which PNC finances our purchase of software and services, which may include but are not limited to third party costs to design, install and implement software systems, and associated hardware described in the schedules defined within the Master IPA. The Master IPA was entered into to finance our implementation of a new enterprise resource planning (&#x201C;ERP&#x201D;) system, which began in October 2012 and is estimated to continue through early 2015. The terms of each note payable under the Master IPA consist of variable interest rates and payment terms based on amounts borrowed and timing of activity throughout the implementation of the ERP system.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of December 31, 2014 and </font><font style="display: inline;">2013, we had $</font><font style="display: inline;">11.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">16.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively, of long-term debt outstanding under </font><font style="display: inline;">five</font><font style="display: inline;"> separate notes payable, </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">of which </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$5.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$5.1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively, represent current installments. As of December 31, 2014, the notes bear interest rates ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2.45%</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2.79%</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">and maturities ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">September 2016</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">September 2017</font><font style="display: inline;">. As this debt arrangement relates solely to the construction and implementation of an ERP system for use by the entity, all interest expense incurred under the arrangement has been capitalized to the consolidated balance sheets until the assets are ready for intended use and will be amortized over the useful life of the software upon that date. During the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013, we capitalized </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$0.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively, in interest expense related to this</font><font style="display: inline;"> debt arrangement to the consolidated balance sheets. Interest rates and payment terms are subject to changes as further financing occurs under the Master IPA. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The aggregate maturities of long-term bank borrowings at December 31, 2014 </font><font style="display: inline;">are as follows (in thousands):</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> 3076000 12100000 1615000 319639000 17230000 5376000 134755000 3005000 814000 44533000 7913000 3356000 13180000 3229000 743000 917000 1838000 61887000 4355000 14590000 1918000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">8</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We transact business in various foreign countries and are therefore exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk inherent in revenues, costs, and monetary assets and liabilities denominated in non-functional currencies. We </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">have </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">enter</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ed</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> into foreign currency exchange forward contract</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and currency swap derivative instruments </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">to selectively protect against volatility in the value of non-functional currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities, and of future cash flows caused by changes in foreig</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n currency exchange rates. We do not designate these</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">derivative instruments</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> as hedging instruments under the accounting standards for derivatives and hedging.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Accordingly, these instruments are recorded at fair value as a derivative asset or liability on the balance sheet with their corresponding change in fair value </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">recognized in &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction losses, net&#x2019; in our consolidated</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> statements of operations. For purposes of the cash flow statement, we classify</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the cash flows at settlement from undesignated instruments in the same category as the cash flows from the related hedged </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">items, generally with</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">in &#x2018;Cash provided by operating activities</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2019; Se</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">e Note 7 &#x2014; Fair Value Measurements for further details regarding the fair values of the corresponding derivative assets and liabilities.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The following table summarizes the notional amounts of the outstanding foreign cur</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rency exchange contracts at </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">December 31, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. The notional amounts of the derivative financial instruments shown below</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> are denominated in their U.S. D</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ollar equivalents and represent the amount of all contracts of the foreign currency specified. These notional values do not necessarily represent amounts exchanged by the parties and, therefore, are not a direct measure of our exposure to the foreign currency exchange risks.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: 100.00%;margin-left:0pt;"> <tr> <td valign="bottom" style="width:57.76%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #C6D9F1;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:16.24%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p transaction losses</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, net&#x2019; on t</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">he </font><font style="display: style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> both realized and unrealized gains/losses from underlying foreign currency activity and derivative contract</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. These gains and losses are reported on a net basis</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. For the year ended December 31, 2014, the net loss recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">9</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million recorded on the consolidated statements of operations is comprised of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$3.8 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million net loss associated with our derivative instruments and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$1.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net loss associated with exposure from day-to-day business transactions in various foreign currencies</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> For</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the year ended December 31, 2013, the n</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">et loss recognized of $4.7 million recorded on the consolidated statements of operations is compr</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ised of a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$17.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> millio</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n net loss associated with exposure from day-to-day business transaction</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s in various foreign currencies </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">partially offset by a</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$13</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net gain associated with our derivative instrument</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. F</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">or the year ended December 31</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, the n</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">et loss recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$2.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million recorded on the consolidated statements of operations is compr</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ised of a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$9.7</font><font million net gain associated with our derivative instrument</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Derivative Foreign Currency Contracts</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We are directly and indirectly affected by fluctuations in foreign currency rates which may adversely impact our financial performance. To mitigate the potential impact of foreign currency exchange rate risk, we may employ derivative financial instruments including forward contracts and option contracts. Forward contracts are agreements to buy or sell a quantity of a currency at a predetermined future date and at a predetermined rate. An option contract is an agreement that conveys the purchaser the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a quantity of a currency at a predetermined rate during a period or at a time in the future. These derivative financial instruments are viewed as risk management tools and are not used for trading or speculative purposes. We recognize derivative financial instruments as either assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets and measure those instruments at fair value. Changes in the fair value of derivatives not designated or effective as hedges are recorded in &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction (gains)/losses, net&#x201D; in the consolidated statements of operations. We had no derivative instruments that qualified for hedge accounting during any of the periods presented. See Note&nbsp;7&#x2014;Fair Value Measurements and Financial Instruments for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">10\. EQUITY</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Equity Incentive Plans</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On August&nbsp;15, 2005, we adopted the 2005 Equity Incentive Plan (the &#x201C;2005 Plan&#x201D;), which permitted the issuance of up to </font><font style="display: inline;">14.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million common shares in connection with the grant of non-qualified stock options, incentive stock options, and restricted stock to eligible employees, consultants and members of our Board. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">0.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">0.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million stock options, respectively, were outstanding under the 2005 Plan. Following the adoption of the 2007 Equity Incentive Plan (the &#x201C;2007 Plan&#x201D;), described below, no additional grants were made under the 2005 Plan.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On July 9, 2007, we adopted and on June 28, 2011 we amended, the 2007 Plan which increased the allowable number of shares of our common stock reserved for issuance under the 2007 Plan from </font><font style="display: inline;">9.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million to </font><font style="display: inline;">15.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million (subject to adjustment for future stock splits, stock dividends and similar changes in our capitalization) in connection with the grant of non-qualified stock options, incentive stock options, restricted stock, restricted stock units, stock appreciation rights, performance units, common stock or any other share-based award to eligible employees, consultants and members of our Board. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">3.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">3.6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million shares of common stock, respectively, were issuable under the 2007 Plan pursuant to outstanding stock options and RSUs. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">3.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million shares were available for future issuance under the </font><font style="display: inline;">2007</font><font style="display: inline;"> Plan.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Restricted stock awards and units generally vest annually on a straight-line basis over </font><font style="display: inline;">three</font><font style="display: inline;"> or </font><font style="display: inline;">four</font><font style="display: inline;"> years depending on the terms of the award agreement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Stock Option Activity</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table summarizes stock option activity for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: 100.00%;margin-left:0pt;"> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:34.80%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:14.90%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: style="width:00.86%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;"> <p #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:15.02%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:00.86%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:20.62%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.75pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:right;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:20.62%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:12.75pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:right;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">4.00</font><font style="display: inline;"> \- </font><font style="display: inline;">4.27</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The weighted-average fair value of options granted during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014, 2013, and 2012 </font><font style="display: inline;">was approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;">5.35</font><font style="display: inline;">, $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.33</font><font style="display: inline;"> and $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.76</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively. The aggregate intrinsic value of options exercised during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> was $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">6.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively. During the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">, we received </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in cash in connection with the exercise of stock options with </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> income tax benefit due to our use of Accounting Standard Codification 740 &#x2013; &#x2018;Income Taxes&#x2019; (with-and-without approach) (&#x201C;ASC 740&#x201D;) ordering for purposes of determining when excess benefits have been realized (see Note&nbsp;12&#x2014;Income Taxes). The total grant date fair value of stock options vested during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> was $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.8 </font><font style="display: inline;">million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million of total unrecognized share-based compensation expense related to unvested options, net of expected forfeitures, which is expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Stock options under both the 2005 Plan and the 2007 Plan generally vest ratably over </font><font style="display: inline;">four</font><font style="display: inline;"> years with the </font><font style="display: inline;">first</font><font style="display: inline;"> year vesting on a &#x201C;cliff&#x201D; basis followed by monthly vesting for the remaining </font><font style="display: inline;">three</font><font style="display: inline;"> years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Restricted Stock Awards and Units </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">From time to time, we grant restricted stock awards (RSAs) and restricted stock units (RSUs) to our employees. RSAs and RSUs generally vest over </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">three</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> or </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">four</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> years, depending on the terms of the grant. Unvested RSAs have the same rights as those of common shares including voting rights and non-forfeitable dividend rights. However, ownership of unvested RSAs cannot be transferred until they are vested. An unvested RSU is a contractual right to receive a share of common stock only upon its vesting. RSUs have dividend equivalent rights which accrue over the term of the award and are paid if and when the RSUs vest, but they have no voting rights.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We typically grant time-based RSUs and performance-based RSUs. Time-based RSUs are typically granted on an annual basis to certain non-executive employees and vest in </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">three</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> annual installments on a straight-line basis beginning one year after the grant date. During the years ended December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012, the Board approved grants of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.3</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million RSUs to certain non-executives. Performance-based RSUs are typically granted on an annual basis to certain executive employees and consist of a time-based and performance-based component. The following represents the vesting schedule of performance-based RSUs granted during the years ended December 31, 2014:</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" &nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Executive may earn from </font><font style="display: the target number of RSUs based on the level of achievement of the performance goal</font></p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;"> &nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="top" style="width:110.20pt;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt solid #000000 ;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;border-right:1pt solid #000000 ;height:212.80pt;padding:0pt 6.5pt"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Earned RSUs vest </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">50%</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> upon satisfaction of performance goal and 50% on the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">one</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">-year anniversary of the end of the Performance Period.</font></p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Earned RSUs vest </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">50%</font><font inline;font-size:10pt;">-year anniversary of the end of the Performance Period.</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font The RSUs vested during the year ended December 31, 2014 consisted of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">30,946</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> performance-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">510,942</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> time-based awards. The RSUs vested during the year ended December 31, 2013 consisted of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">52,288</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> performance-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;">277,254</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;color:#000000;"> time-based awards.&nbsp;&nbsp;The RSUs vested during the year ended December 31, 2012 consisted entirely of time-based awards.&nbsp; </font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">The total grant date fair value of RSAs vested during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> was $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.0</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.8</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million, respectively. As of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, we had $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">0.1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million of total unrecognized share-based compensation expense related to non-vested restricted stock awards, net of expected forfeitures, all of which was related to time-based awards. The unvested RSAs are expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">0.36</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">The total grant date fair value of RSUs vested during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> was $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">9.6</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">7.1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">3.1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million, respectively. As of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, we had $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">13.0</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million of total unrecognized share-based compensation expense related to unvested restricted stock units, net of expected forfeitures, of which </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$6.2</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million is related to performance-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$6.8</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million is time-based awards. The unvested RSUs are expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.49</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;years, which consists of a remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.15</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> years related to performance-based awards and a remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">1.78</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> years related to time-based awards.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">Share-based Compensation</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">During the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, we recorded </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$12.7</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$12.5</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">11.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;million, respectively, of pre-tax share-based compensation expense </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">of which </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$0.2</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$0.7</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$0.0</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million, respectively, related solely to the construction and implementation of our ERP system for use by the entity was capitalized to the consolidated balance sheets until assets are ready for intended use and </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">will be amortized over the useful life of the software upon that date</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">. &nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">Separation Agreements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">On December 27, 2013, John McCarvel resigned from his position as President, Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and director of the Company effective April 30, 2014. Also on December 27, 2013, the Company and Mr. McCarvel entered into a separation agreement providing that the Company will pay Mr. McCarvel (i) a </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$1.1</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million separation payment on the first regularly scheduled payroll date after the effectiveness of his resignation and (ii) a </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$1.0</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million separation payment on the first anniversary of the effectiveness of his resignation. In accordance with </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">ASC </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;color:#000000;">420</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;color:#000000;"> &#x2013; Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">, the Company recognized the first and second installment payments of $1.1 million and $1.0 million ratably from December 27, 2013 through April 30, 2014. Mr. McCarvel was also entitled to receive any amount earned pursuant to the Company&#x2019;s 2013 annual incentive program, in such form and at such time as is provided under the terms of such program.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">Pursuant to the separation agreement, unvested share awards that vested through April 30, 2014 amounted to </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">58,840</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> shares. </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;color:#000000;">Additionally, pursuant to the terms of the separation agreement, Mr. McCarvel forfeited </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;color:#000000;">388,745</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;color:#000000;"> share awards which did not vest through April 30, 2014.</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> The separation payments are conditioned upon the effectiveness of Mr. McCarvel&#x2019;s release of claims in favor of the Company and his compliance with the non-competition, non-solicitation and confidentiality covenants contained in the separation agreement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">Appointment of President and Interim CEO</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">On May 13, 2014, the Board appointed Andrew Rees as President of the Company with principal responsibilities for the Crocs brand, effective June 9, 2014. In addition, the Board appointed Mr. Rees as principal executive officer to serve until such time as the Board appoints a Chief Executive Officer of the Company, which it did effective January 28, 2015. Upon commencement of his employment, Mr. Rees was granted an RSU award representing to right to receive shares of our common stock equal to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$197,534</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">, based on the closing price of our common stock on the date immediately prior to his start date, which vests in </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">three</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> annual installments beginning on the first anniversary of his start date, subject to his continued employment with us as of each vesting date. In addition, Mr. Rees was granted an RSU award representing the right to receive shares of our common stock equal to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$3,500,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">, based on a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> day weighted-average stock price as of May 13, 2014, and such RSU award shall vest based on achievement of certain share price levels before the fourth anniversary of his start date, subject to his continued employment with us. For calendar years after 2014, Mr. Rees is also eligible to participate in the Company&#x2019;s long-term incentive plan, with a target grant value of no less than </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$700,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">, except that the target grant value in 2015 shall be </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$897,534</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">Appointment of CEO</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">On December 12, 2014, Gregg Ribatt was appointed our Chief Executive Officer, effective January 28, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with his appointment as Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Ribatt was granted a sign-on time-vesting RSU award representing the right to receive shares of our common stock equal to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$2,000,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">, based on a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">-day weighted-average stock price as of December 15, 2014. This time-vesting RSU award will vest in three annual installments beginning on the first anniversary of his start date, subject to his continued employment with us as of each vesting date. In addition, Mr. Ribatt was granted a sign-on performance-vesting RSU award, subject to various vesting criteria, representing the right to receive shares of our common stock equal to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$6,000,000</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">, based on a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">-day weighted-average stock price as of December 15, 2014. Based on a Monte-Carlo valuation model, the fair value of the RSU was determined to be </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">$2.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> million, or </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">46.0%</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> of the grant price, which will be expensed on a straight-line basis over a derived service period of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;">2.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;color:#000000;"> years, beginning in 2015.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 3067000 11301000 11301000 1.46 0.33 0.12 0.40 0.15 -0.76 0.06 -0.22 0.19 0.12 -0.70 1.44 0.33 0.12 0.40 0.15 -0.76 0.06 -0.22 0.19 0.12 -0.70 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Earnings per Share</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;"> Basic and diluted earnings per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted-average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is a security that may participate in undistributed earnings with common stock had those earnings been distributed in any form. Our recently issued Series A convertible preferred stock (&#x201C;Series A Preferred Stock&#x201D;) represents participating securities as holders of the Series A Preferred Stock are entitled to receive any and all dividends declared or paid on common stock on an as-converted basis. In addition, shares of our non-vested restricted stock awards are considered participating securities as they represent unvested share-based payment awards containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends. As such, these participating securities must be included in the computation of EPS pursuant to the two-class method on a pro-rata, as-converted basis. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in our earnings. In addition, the dilutive effect of each participating security is calculated using the more dilutive of the two-class method described above, which assumes that the securities remain in their current form, or the if-converted method, which assumes conversion to common stock as of the beginning of the reporting date. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS. See </font><font style="display: inline;">Note 13&#x2014;Earnings Per Share</font><font style="display: inline;"> for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">13\. EARNINGS PER SHARE</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 4pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table illustrates the basic and diluted earnings </font><font style="display: inline;">(loss) pe</font><font style="display: inline;">r share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) computations for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">See Note 1 &#x2013; Organization &amp; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies for additional detail regarding our EPS calculations.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> EPS as their effect would have been anti-dilutive.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Stock Repurchase Plan Authorizations</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We continue to evaluate options to maximize the returns on our cash and maintain an appropriate capital structure, including, among other alternatives, repurchases of our common stock. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 our common stock. This authorization effectively replaced our previous stock repurchase authorizations. The number, price, structure and timing of the repu</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rchases </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">will be at our sole discretion and future repurchases will be evaluated by us depending on market conditions, liquidity needs and other factors. Share repurchases may be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The repurchase authorization does not have an expiration date and does not oblige us to acquire any particular amount of our common stock. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Our B</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">oard may suspend, modify or terminate the repurchase program at any time without prior notice.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">During the year ended December 31, 2014, we repurchased </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">10.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million shares</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> at a weighted-average </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">price of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$13.75</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> per share for an aggregate price </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$145.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million excluding</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> related commission charges under our publicly-an</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">no</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">unced repurchase plan. FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following tables summarize the financial instruments required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis as of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">3</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:11.20%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:15.75pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:00.86%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:15.75pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.00%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;height:15.75pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:02.00%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: valign="bottom" style="width:09.40%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: &nbsp;-</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:00.86%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 valign="bottom" style="width:02.00%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: style="width:00.86%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:25.20pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;text-align:right;color:#000000;font-family:Times New Roman;overflow: hidden;font-size:0pt;"> &nbsp;</p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:28.02%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9
